page.title: 10Landscapes.
page.content: Most travellers stick to the few main roads that cross the Pennines. But the seemingly impenetrable hills conceal a multitude of villages tucked away in hidden green valleys, or clinging to steep hillsides. The M57 leads on to one such village, called Mottram. Once isolated communities, the inhabitants of these villages leading into the Pennines, retain the independent spirit and dogged perserverance of the days when even a short journey was hazardous. Mottram used to contain only the traditional stone-built cottages, typical of the area. The heavy stone lintels, made of one enormous piece of stone, were characteristic. The local stone was used for the Church, and for the thirteenth century Old Hall, the oldest remaining secular building, which is now a fish and chip shop.
